headline: Court Reinstates Florida Congressional Map
author: Alexa Corse
sentences: To avoid uncertainty and confusion in the upcoming 2022 primary and general elections, its important to move forward expeditiously to implement the congressional map passed by the legislature and signed by the governor,? his office said.

In March, Mr. DeSantis vetoed a map created by the Republican-controlled Legislature, saying lawmakers created a racial gerrymander by trying to draw a district focused on Black voters in northern Florida.

One of the most significant changes in Mr. DeSantiss map was the dismantling of the plurality-Black Fifth Congressional District, which extends from Jacksonville in the east to Tallahassee in the west.

The judge said the map likely violated a state constitutional amendment that prohibited drawing districts in ways that deny racial minorities equal opportunity to elect representatives of their choice.
Voting groups, including Black Voters Matter and the League of Women Voters of Florida, sued last month to block Mr. DeSantiss map, saying it would reduce the representation of Black voters.
The governors office has said the map wasnt based on racial or partisan data and that it was better than other proposals because it hewed more closely to geographic and political boundaries.
Todays ruling does nothing to change the fact that the Governors proposed map is a blatantly unconstitutional attack on Black representation in Florida,? they said after the ruling.
In a special legislative session Mr. DeSantis convened in April, lawmakers approved a map proposed by the governor that was expected to add four Republican seats.
The two-page order issued Friday by the First District Court of Appeal in Tallahassee disagreed with that decision, saying it upset the status quo.

The courts order Friday puts back into effect Mr. DeSantiss map, the latest development in a case that has swung back and forth in recent weeks.
That map likely would have added two Republican seats to the states House delegation, according to the Cook Political Report.
